Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: KONTAK Hydrogen Liquid Storage Reactor
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I Project is designed to enable the wide acceptance of hydrogen as a green alternative to gasoline and diesel. To accomplish this goal, a way had to be found to safely and economically store, transport and use hydrogen. A class of organic compounds has been discovered that can store hydrogen, release it as needed, and form a recyclable residual compounds. By holding hydrogen on a liquid carrier at normal temperatures and pressures, the cost and complexity of compressing or liquefying hydrogen has been eliminated. The same infrastructure that supplies us with gasoline, diesel and ethanol can be used without modification to transport this hydrogen liquid. A safe and economical means for capturing, storing, transporting and dispensing hydrogen will enable green technologies for making hydrogen from wind, solar, biomass and tidal energy. Possibilities exist for using CO2 as a component to make these carrier molecules from hydrated ethanol. Hydrogen can be mixed 50/50 with diesel fuel to cut harmful diesel emissions in half including diesel soot which has been implicated in the rise in childhood asthma.

This project combines the skills of organic chemists, nanotechnology, 3D fabrication engineers and computer-controlled electronics drivers to deliver a novel result. Achieving uniform heating of a catalytic volume is key to producing the desired output without byproducts and fouling of the catalytic surfaces. Since the anticipated reactions are endothermic and the flow rates for commercial applications are high, the research is focused on developing precise control of heat transfer into the reactor core through design and experiments. The experimental plan also involves evaluation of multiple materials for the induction heating elements, the effect of location in the solenoid barrel of the reactor core, and the various methods available to bind multiple, very small Reactor tubes together to create the Cores. The goal is to demonstrate capability for generating hydrogen output of 33 gaseous liters per
minute for a 5 kW fuel cell.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Phase I Project Outcomes Report  1722037

Enabling the Hydrogen Economy

KONTAK, LLC is a start-up company with deep roots in the field of hydrogen storage and transportation.  Our scientists and engineers have created a very promising device for extracting hydrogen from liquid organic molecules (Carriers).  This technique removes hydrogen while creating a recyclable residual molecule.  We call it a Reactor Module.  During Phase I, it was designed, built and demonstrated to extract hydrogen (Figure 1).  Future progress will be rapid for creating a world-wide hydrogen storage and transportation network delivering on the decades-long promises of the Hydrogen Economy.

The KONTAK Reactor Module is key: providing an energy-efficient method for extracting hydrogen that is compact in size, low in cost and inherently safe in operation.  The proposed Carriers are projected to be as safe as gasoline or diesel fuel.

The use of hydrogen as an energy carrier has been stalled due to the high cost of hydrogen, inefficient fuel cells and lack of an affordable distribution infrastructure.  Fuel cell efficiencies have been increasing rapidly reaching 60% in 2017.  KONTAK’s Reactor Module breakthrough opens the door to clean hydrogen delivered at costs comparable to gasoline or diesel.  By storing hydrogen bonded to a Carrier, the cost of storage and transportation is cut to 25% that of compressed hydrogen.  Because the Carriers are liquid at normal temperatures and pressures, they can be stored and transported using conventional steel tanks, ocean-going ships, rail cars and trucks.  Hydrogen can be produced anywhere in the world and transported inexpensively thousands of miles to market.  Because there is no hydrogen gas with the Carrier, our method is far safer than compressed hydrogen.

The ability to recycle the Carrier by adding more hydrogen combined with traditional methods of storage and transportation allow KONTAK hydrogen to be delivered to fueling stations for $2.85 per kilogram.  Compare that to $10.00 to $15.00 for today’s compressed hydrogen.  Removing hydrogen on-board a vehicle only as needed allows KONTAK fueling stations to store liquids, not compressed hydrogen.  The price of a station falls to 1/10th the cost of a compressed hydrogen station that is currently over $2M.  KONTAK stations can be factory-built anywhere in the world in 20-foot shipping containers.  This novel approach allows thousands of inexpensive stations to be put in place per year to solve the hydrogen infrastructure problem.

Today, most hydrogen is made from methane, a greenhouse gas, that produces CO2.  KONTAK’s storage and transportation method allows hydrogen to be made inexpensively from flare gas at major oil fields.  By capturing the CO2 by-product and pumping it back into the field to pressurize it, hydrogen is obtained with negative CO2.  Methane is not flared, but converted to hydrogen and the CO2 is sequestered on site.  Green hydrogen can also be produced by water electrolysis using wind and solar, but currently these methods are more expensive than methane reforming.

How will these potentially huge quantities of green hydrogen be used today?  An immediate market would be to combine 8% hydrogen in natural gas distribution networks.  Hydrogen can also be co-combusted up to 60% in diesel engines of all sizes from delivery trucks to Class-8 tractors to locomotives and even ships at sea.  Another societal benefit from co-combusting hydrogen and diesel fuel is the virtual elimination of dangerous diesel soot particles (up to 90% according to tests performed in the UK).

As fuel cells become even more prevalent, they will represent large markets for hydrogen in the future.  Applications already using fuel cells in large numbers today are aerial drones, fork lift trucks, back-up power generators, along with electric cars, trucks and buses.

Specific outcomes: under Phase I, KONTAK has designed a method to rapidly and uniformly heat a catalyst volume to 300°C in less than 2 minutes using induction heating.  The proof of our claim comes from infrared (heat) movies taken with a special video camera (Figure 2).  The first application of this technique has been to release hydrogen, but potentially it will have many other applications in the future.

KONTAK intends to apply for a Phase II Grant to commercialize its technology and to deploy its technology as rapidly as possible by offering licenses to qualified organizations.  For more information, see our Web Site at https://kontakhydrogenstorage.com/
